awd_titl_txt: Imparting Nobility to Base-Metal Hydrides for CO2 Hydrogenation
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Connie Lu of the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities is developing molecular catalysts to transform carbon dioxide into useful chemicals and/or liquid fuels. Sustainable processes for producing commodity chemicals and for storing energy are increasingly relevant to a secure energy future. Because of its abundance and ease of handling, carbon dioxide has the potential to serve as a renewable single-carbon feedstock for the chemical industry. Professor Lu is using catalysts featuring earth-abundant metals addressing a broader challenge in catalysis: to replace traditional catalytic metals with cheaper, available alternatives. Besides building experience in catalysis research, graduate students are trained to collaborate across traditional disciplinary boundaries and gain workforce-related training abroad. Outreach activities focus on teaching catalysis and energy to K-12 students through experiments and/or demonstrations.

The bimetallic catalysts being developed for carbon dioxide hydrogenation feature base metals (Ni, Co, and Fe) supported by Lewis acidic Group 13 ions. The premise of the proposed work is that the Lewis acidic center will be a powerful lever to tune the reactivity at the base metal. Extensive effort is dedicated to mechanistic investigations using a combination of synthetic, spectroscopic, and theoretical approaches to evaluate how catalytic activity depend on the supporting ion. Key intermediates are isolated and characterized, including novel anionic metal hydrides, whose negative charges result in high reactivity. Hydride transfer to other substrates with polar C=O substrates is also investigated. The work builds knowledge about how to leverage Lewis acid supports, so to endow higher selectivity and/or efficiency to base-metal active sites. Assessing the impact of the Lewis acid support on catalytic efficiency and selectivity leads to catalyst descriptions, both experimental and theoretical in nature, which may be transferrable to other catalyst systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Sustainable processes for producing commodity chemicals and for storing energy are increasingly relevant to a secure energy future. Carbon dioxide, a waste product of many industrial processes, has the potential to be an abundant and cheap resource for making liquid fuels and building important chemicals. Reuse of waste carbon dioxide is limited by the lack of economical and efficient chemical processes. With NSF support, Professor Connie Lu at the University of Minnesota has developed new catalysts that replace precious metal catalysts with earth-abundant alternatives to catalyze the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to formate, a commodity chemical and a potential storage of H2 as an alternative fuel.

The state-of-the-art catalysts for carbon dioxide hydrogenation typically use a precious metal element such as rhodium or ruthenium.  Replacing these with base metals that are earth abundant and cheap, such as nickel, cobalt, and iron, will be critical to make viable the reuse of waste carbon dioxide. A scientific challenge is that simple replacement of a precious metal with a base metal results in poor activity. Hence, efficient base metal catalysts requires novel design. Professor Lu demonstrated that bimetallic catalysts that bond a base metal with a Lewis acidic group 13 ion become highly active catalysts for carbon dioxide hydrogenation. No activity is observed when the Lewis acidic ion is absent, or if the bonding interaction is disrupted.

Because of NSF funding for this project, the following key discoveries and achievements were made:

  1. The nickel-gallium catalyst gave 3,000+ turnovers of formate with an initial turnover frequency of 9,700 formate per hour at ambient temperature with stoichiometric Verkade?s base and 34 atm 1:1 H2:CO2. This level of activity had been unprecedented for single nickel catalysts.
  2. The cobalt-gallium catalyst gave 19,000+ turnovers of formate with an initial turnover frequency of 27,000 formate per hour under similar conditions. The activity compares favorably to the very best cobalt-based catalysts previously reported.
  3. Key reactive intermediates were isolated and characterized both spectroscopically and structurally by single-crystal X-ray/neutron diffraction. The identification of these intermediates provided detailed insight into the catalytic mechanism. Moreover, the successful isolation of these reactive species were among the first for an anionic nickel hydride, and among the few examples of non-classical H2 adducts for base metals.
  4. Nickel-lanthanide bimetallic complexes were successfully prepared and the nature of the lanthanide support was demonstrated to determine the regio- and chemoselectivity in the hydrogenation of disubstituted alkynes to E-alkenes. This is a rare study where the electronic perturbation of a metalloligand is shown to tune both activity and selectivity.
  5. A total of eight manuscripts have been published to disseminate our findings: two articles in the Journal of the American Chemical Society, two articles in ACS Catalysis, and two articles in Chemical Science, one article in Angewandte Chemie, and one article in European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry.  

Three PhD students were trained and graduated based on their work on this project. One of these students, a female Hispanic, will bring more diversity to the U.S. STEM workforce. To broaden their skill set, researchers hone laboratory skills and engage with interdisciplinary collaborators at U.S. national laboratories and the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion in Germany through short research stays and training workshops. Five graduate researchers on this project volunteered as SciMentors, an outreach program that serves underprivileged adult learners by tutoring them for the GED exam, a high school equivalency credential, and by engaging them with hands-on science experiments.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2021
Modified by: Connie C Lu

por.por_txt_cntn:
Sustainable processes for producing commodity chemicals and for storing energy are increasingly relevant to a secure energy future. Carbon dioxide, a waste product of many industrial processes, has the potential to be an abundant and cheap resource for making liquid fuels and building important chemicals. Reuse of waste carbon dioxide is limited by the lack of economical and efficient chemical processes. A scientific challenge is that simple replacement of a precious metal with a base metal results in poor activity. Hence, efficient base metal catalysts requires novel design. The cobalt-gallium catalyst gave 19,000+ turnovers of formate with an initial turnover frequency of 27,000 formate per hour under similar conditions. The activity compares favorably to the very best cobalt-based catalysts previously reported.
Key reactive intermediates were isolated and characterized both spectroscopically and structurally by single-crystal X-ray/neutron diffraction. The identification of these intermediates provided detailed insight into the catalytic mechanism. Nickel-lanthanide bimetallic complexes were successfully prepared and the nature of the lanthanide support was demonstrated to determine the regio- and chemoselectivity in the hydrogenation of disubstituted alkynes to E-alkenes. This is a rare study where the electronic perturbation of a metalloligand is shown to tune both activity and selectivity.
A total of eight manuscripts have been published to disseminate our findings: two articles in the Journal of the American Chemical Society, two articles in ACS Catalysis, and two articles in Chemical Science, one article in Angewandte Chemie, and one article in European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry.  


Three PhD students were trained and graduated based on their work on this project. One of these students, a female Hispanic, will bring more diversity to the U.S. STEM workforce. To broaden their skill set, researchers hone laboratory skills and engage with interdisciplinary collaborators at U.S. national laboratories and the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion in Germany through short research stays and training workshops. Five graduate researchers on this project volunteered as SciMentors, an outreach program that serves underprivileged adult learners by tutoring them for the GED exam, a high school equivalency credential, and by engaging them with hands-on science experiments.
